message_1: Suppose you have a dataset containing the ages of 100 students in a mathematics class. The mean age of students is 20 years, with a standard deviation of 2.5 years. If a new student is added to the class who is 23 years old, what is the z-score of the new student's age in relation to the rest of the class?
message_2:
To calculate the z-score of the new student's age, we will use the following formula:

z = (X - μ) / σ

where z is the z-score, X is the value (in this case, the new student's age), μ is the mean, and σ is the standard deviation.

Given the mean age (μ) is 20 years and the standard deviation (σ) is 2.5 years, we can plug in the values:

z = (23 - 20) / 2.5
z = 3 / 2.5
z = 1.2

The z-score of the new student's age is 1.2, which means the new student's age is 1.2 standard deviations above the mean age of the class.
